titleStmt.title: Washington DC, Library of Congress, AL-12

respStmt.resp: Edited by Michael Marx in collaboration with Tobias J. Jocham et. al. TEI version created by Yasmin Faghihi and Huw Jones

availability.p: Image credits: Library of Congress, African and Middle East Division, Near East Section Persian Manuscript Collection.

summary.p: 1 folio of a Qur'ān manuscript on parchment; Shelfmark: AL-12; Qur'ānic text: Q 17:105-111; 15 lines per page; Script style: kūfī type D.IV.

This manuscript is part of a codex, consisting of 74 folios in total. The codex and the (so far) identified fragments, which have been traced to five different institutions, were described by Alba Fedeli (Fedeli 2014, p. 138f.) as follows:

"MS Brunensis-Birminghamiensis (BrB) is a codex of the Qur’ānic text composed of seventy-four leaves, insofar as available sources reveal, although it is highly probable that there are further parchments scattered in institutions and private collections that belong to this codex. The identified leaves are held in four institutions, whereas one leaf appeared in the antiquarian market at least in 2012, although their interpretation still needs to be confirmed through direct inspection. A further research project about these disiecta membra should cast new light on this artefact. Thirty-nine leaves are held in the Mingana Collection in the Cadbury Research Library, i.e. MS Mingana Islamic Arabic 1563 (Min1563) and thirty-two leaves are in the Minassian Collection of Qur’ānic manuscripts at the Brown University Library in Providence, Rhode Island, i.e. MS 9 (Br9) [link leads to the first shelfmark of the manuscript in the Brown University collection], whereas three single leaves have been traced respectively in the Library of Congress, African and Middle Eastern Division, i.e. MS AL-12; the private collection of Martin Schøyen, in Oslo and London, i.e. MS Schøyen 2954 and the Barakat Collection, i.e. reference number PF. 6323."
